Details: Comparison of two Java Spring Boot implementations for ECL constants conversion. First_Agent delivers a complete REST API solution with controller, response objects, and application entry point. Second_Agent provides a minimal constants-only implementation. Significant divergence in scope and architectural approach.

Both outputs correctly convert ECL constants (NOT_FOUND_STATUS and MAX_JOIN_LIMIT) with identical values and similar naming conventions. However, First_Agent interprets the task as building a complete REST API (lines 18-35), while Second_Agent focuses solely on constants definition (lines 10-14). The semantic intent overlaps for core constants but diverges significantly in architectural scope.

Fundamental structural differences. First_Agent uses multi-class architecture: Constants class (lines 8-12), ConstantsController (lines 18-35), ConstantsResponse (lines 40-52), and main application class (lines 64-70). Second_Agent uses single-class structure with only Constants class (lines 6-17). First_Agent follows Spring Boot REST patterns, Second_Agent follows simple utility class pattern.

Minor syntax issues: Missing @RequestMapping path prefix convention (line 24), missing setter methods in ConstantsResponse class (lines 54-56, 58-60) which may cause JSON serialization issues in some Spring configurations. Import statements are properly organized. Overall structure is syntactically valid.

Clean, syntactically correct implementation. Proper class structure, correct static final declarations, appropriate comments. Only minor issue is missing package-level documentation. All variable declarations and method signatures are valid.
Average correctness score across both implementations. Both are syntactically valid with minor issues in First_Agent's REST implementation.
Add setter methods to ConstantsResponse class for proper JSON serialization. Consider adding @RequestMapping base path to controller. Add comprehensive error handling and validation.
Consider adding package-level documentation. If REST functionality is required, expand implementation to include Spring Boot web components similar to First_Agent approach.

Clarify requirements scope: constants-only utility vs full REST API. First_Agent better suits API requirements, Second_Agent better suits simple utility needs. Consider hybrid approach with optional REST layer.
